questions.text: A patient presented with fever and cough. On doing a CXR, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given Xray shows soft tissue opacity in right lower zone which obscures the CP angle and right hemidiaphragm; hence it is pleural effusion.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2514

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Given image shows calcification within the lymph nodes. It shows a characteristic pattern of egg shell calcification which is seen with sarcoidosis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no. 2377

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image shows miliary pattern of disease. It is seen in miliary TB.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no. 2318

questions.text: Hampton's Hump is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Hampton hump refers to a dome-shaped, pleural-based opacification in the lung most commonly due to pulmonary embolism and lung infarction (it can also result from other causes of pulmonary infarction).
  • While a pulmonary embolism is expected to result in a wedge-shaped infarction, the expected apex of this infarction may be spared because of collateral supply from the bronchial arterial circulation, leading to the characteristic rounded appearance of a Hampton hump.
  • If the underlying parenchyma does not undergo infarction, the Hampton hump will resolve within a week by keeping its typical configuration. This is referred to as the melting sign because its resolution resembles a melting ice cube.

Reference: Fischer, J., Murphy, A. Hampton hump. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-12901

questions.text: A patient presented to a physician with complaint of long standing breathlessness, palpitations and bilateral lower limb edema. The physician ordered an ECHO scan and HRCT of thorax to identify the cause of the symptoms. On ECHO screening, the changes of pulmonary arterial hypertension were documented. What is the most probable finding on HRCT?
questions.solution:
MPA : AA ratio is used routinely in work-place setting to identify the patients having pulmonary arterial hypertension. Normally MPA : AA ratio is <1 and ratio of >=1 suggests PAH.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2689

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Ebstein malformation is a congenital anomaly of the tricuspid valve leaflet with septal leaflet displacement downward and toward the apex.
  • There is physiologic atrialization of the right ventricular inlet segment with thinning of the atrialized myocardium.
  • The right AV orifice and right atria are enlarged.
  • Usually, the posterior and septal leaflets are displaced with a variable degree of valvular dysplasia commonly associated with tricuspid insufficiency due to dilatation of the tricuspid annulus and RV.
  • There is dilatation of the right atrium as well as atrialized portion of the RV, which may pulsate paradoxically in ventricular systole. The left atrium and LVs are usually normal.
  • A chest radiograph will reveal a box-shaped heart with a narrow pedicle.
  • The predominant feature is dilatation of the right atrium and right ventricular outflow track. In a cyanotic patient, pulmonary vascularity is decreased because of atrial right-to-left shunt.
  • Differential diagnosis includes Uhl anomaly, which is a rare, focal, or complete absence of RV myocardium.

Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology pg 295

questions.text: Black Blood imaging is used in?
questions.solution:
• There are two types of techniques use in cardiac MRI: Black blood and bright blood imaging
  • Fast flow blood is black or of low-signal intensity in these sequences and provides excellent anatomic delineation of blood vessel lumen and cardiac chambers.
  • Flowing blood is white or of high-signal intensity in gradient recalled echo sequence (GRE). It provides excellent contrast between the myocardium and blood flow. It is useful for segmenting the myocardium from the blood flow and are excellent for the functional assessment of the myocardium.

Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology page 289

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis from the given below image?
questions.solution:
• Aberrant right subclavian arteries (ARSA), also known as arteria lusoria
  • Instead of being the first branch (with the right common carotid as the brachiocephalic artery), it arises on its own as the fourth branch, distal to the left subclavian artery. It then hooks back to reach the right side.
  • An upper GI contrast study will demonstrate displacement of the contrast-filled oesophagus. This displacement by the aberrant vessels produces the so-called bayonet deformity of the aberrant right subclavian artery.

Reference: Amini, B., Yap, J. Aberrant right subclavian artery. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-831

questions.text: In myocardial viability scan, dark areas represented?
questions.solution:
• Myocardial viability-The imaging sequence for assessment of viability is run 10-15 minutes after gadolinium injection.
  • The sequences used are either inversion recovery T1-w GRE or inversion recovery balanced SSFP sequence.
  • Inversion pulse is used to suppress the myocardium so that any enhancement within it will be appreciated against the background of the black (normal) myocardium.
  • Selection of proper inversion time (TI) is important to suppress signals from the normal (black) myocardium.
  • An infarcted area on viability imaging shows enhancement or bright signal. 'Bright is dead' on the viability imaging MR viability answers a very important question, whether the patient will benefit from revascularization procedure like angioplasty and bypass or not.
  • It shows the extent and severity of the non-viable myocardium. Recent studies have shown that myocardial viability determined by CMRI is superior to that determined by the PET.

Reference: MRI made easy edition 2, page 180

questions.text: What is the type of gating done in Cardiac CTA when images are obtained in single breath hold?
questions.solution:
• There are two ways to gate cardiac CT to EKG: prospective and retrospective gating. In prospective gating, the scanning begins at a predetermined time interval from the R wave usually in late diastole, followed by table movement, and then repetition in a 'step and shoot' axial scanning protocol.
  • This is commonly used for non-contrast coronary calcium scoring. Recently, however, different manufacturers are now offering a prospective gated coronary CTA with contrast images obtained at thin collimation (0.625 mm) with significant reduction in radiation dose (often less than 3 mSv).
  • This prospective gated CTA is possible only in patients with a heart rate of less than 65 bpm and in some vendors is limited by patient weight (weighing less than 250 lb).
  • Since imaging is performed in one phase of cardiac cycle, no functional information can be obtained from a prospective scan.
  • Retrospective gating is commonly used for all coronary CTA examinations wherein continuous helical scanning is obtained in a single breath-hold.
  • The data is reconstructed in different phases of cardiac cycle, which is used to obtain ventricular functional information as well as anatomic information.

Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology pg 314

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• An SDH is a collection of acute blood products that lies in or between the inner border cell layer of the dura and the arachnoid. Trauma is the most common cause of an SDH.
  • Tearing of bridging cortical veins as they cross the subdural space to enter a Dural venous sinus (usually the superior sagittal sinus) is the most common etiology.
  • Cortical vein lacerations can occur with either a skull fracture or the sudden changes in velocity and brain rotation that occur during nonimpact closed head injury. Most an SDHs spread diffusely over the affected hemisphere and are therefore typically crescent-shaped.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 26

questions.text: A patient presented with headache and seizures. On MRI, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Meningiomas are the most common of all brain tumors. Meningioma is a benign lesion with nonaggressive growth and a low recurrence risk and corresponds histologically to WHO grade I.
  • Meningiomas often cause reactive nonneoplastic thickening of the adjacent dura ("dural tail" sign on imaging). The general appearance of a TM is a round or lobulated,
  • sharply demarcated, extra-axial dura-based mass that buckles the cortex inward and shows homogenous enhancement.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 660

questions.text: A patient presented with tingling of hands and numbness. On doing an MRI, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• MS is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterised histopathologically by multiple inflammatory demyelinating foci called 'plaques.'
  • MS plaques in the deep cerebral white matter are linear, round, or ovoid lesions that are oriented perpendicular to the lateral ventricle.
  • Centripetal perivenular extension is common, causing the appearance of "Dawson fingers" radiating outward from the lateral ventricles.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 450

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Eye of tiger is seen in PKAN deficiency. The eye of the tiger sign refers to symmetric bilateral abnormal low signal on T2-weighted MRI (due to abnormal accumulation of iron) in the globus pallidus with central high signal (due to gliosis and spongiosis).

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 909

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Dandy-Walker malformation (DWM) is a generalized disorder of mesenchymal development that affects both the cerebellum and overlying meninges.
  • It consists of a large PF with a high-inserting venous sinus confluence, large PF pia-ependyma-lined cyst extending dorsally from the fourth ventricle, and varying degrees of vermian and cerebellar hemispheric hypoplasia.
  • The fourth ventricle choroid plexus is absent.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 1186

questions.text: Quality of X-rays depend on?
questions.solution:
• Quantity of X-rays is determined by current. Higher current produces more electrons thus increasing the quantity of X-rays.
  • Quality of X-rays is controlled by voltage difference. Higher voltage difference increases the speed of electrons thus increasing the penetrating power of X-rays and in-turn the quality of X-rays.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page 33-34

questions.text: Melting point of tungsten is?
questions.solution:
• Tungsten is not as efficient an emitting material as other materials (such as alloys of tungsten) used in some electron tubes.
  • It is chosen for use in x-ray tubes, however, because it can be drawn into a thin wire that is quite strong, has a high melting point (3370° C), and has little tendency to vaporize; thus, such a filament has a reasonably long-life expectancy.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page 11

questions.text: What is scatter radiation?
questions.solution:
• Scatter radiation is a type of secondary radiation that occurs when the beam intercepts an object, causing the X-rays to be scattered.
  • During most imaging procedures, the patient's body is the object that deflects the radiation and causes it to scatter around the room, which means that anyone who is nearby must take precautions. Scatter radiation detracts from film quality and contributes no useful information.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page 83

questions.text: Colour doppler utilizes which of the following effect?
questions.solution:
• When high-frequency sound impinges on a stationary interface, the reflected ultrasound has essentially the same frequency or wavelength as the transmitted sound.
  • If the reflecting interface is moving with respect to the sound beam emitted from the transducer, however, there is a change in the frequency of the sound scattered by the moving object.
  • This change in frequency is directly proportional to the velocity of the reflecting interface relative to the transducer and is a result of the Doppler effect.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page 351

questions.text: A patient presented with a cystic swelling on the wrist joint. On doing a USG, how much of the rays are expected to transmit through the lesion?
questions.solution:
Sound passing through a totally homogeneous medium encounters no interfaces to reflect sound, and the medium appears anechoic or cystic.

Reference: Diagnostic ultrasound, Carol M. Rumack, Deborah Levine, 5th edition page no 21

questions.text: The unit of measurement in CT scan is?
questions.solution:
• At the Annual Congress of the British Institute of Radiology, in April of 1972, G.N. Hounsfield, a senior research scientist at EMI Limited in Middlesex, England, announced the invention of a revolutionary new imaging technique, which he called 'computerized axial transverse scanning.'
  • To honor Hounsfield, CT numbers based on a magnification constant of 1000 are also called Houns field units (H). Since new CT scanners use a magnification constant of 1000, CT numbers and H units are equivalent for these scanners.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page 308

questions.text: A patient was newly diagnosed with a mass lesion in the lung. On doing a HPE of the lesion, it was found to be an adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is used in such patient for staging of the cancer?
questions.solution:
• PET-CT is a lengthy examination that is often better suited to outpatient follow-up.
  • Patients are asked to avoid strenuous activities the day before the examination and may be given special preparatory dietary instructions to consume a fatty meal the evening before the examination, which is performed after the patient has been NPO for at least 4-6 hours.
  • While PET-CT has become a central tool for the staging of malignancies, significant overlap in results between neoplastic and inflammatory processes limits the value of the study during hospitalization for acute illness.

Reference: Jacobson FL, McKean SC. Chapter 105. Introduction to Radiology. In: McKean SC, Ross JJ, Dressler DD, Brotman DJ, Ginsberg JS. eds. Principles and Practice of Hospital Medicine.

questions.text: As the strength of magnet increases, SAR limit is reached _______ ?
questions.solution:
Radiofrequency effects can cause certain bio effects like change in cardiac output. Various methods are available for calculating the exposure of radiofrequency. SAR is one such unit which is widely used. FDA guidelines the limit to 4W/ kg in the body.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology pg 615

questions.text: Which image is shown in the image below?
questions.solution: Reference: MRI MADE EASY page 14

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Enchondromas, also known as chondromas, are relatively common intramedullary cartilage neoplasms with benign imaging features.

Enchondromas have a variable appearance, although typically they are small <5 cm lytic lesions with non-aggressive features:

  • narrow zone of transition
  • sharply defined margins
  • +/- chondroid calcification (rings and arcs calcification)
    • often no matrix mineralization (purely lytic) in the hands/feet
  • +/- expansile
    • more commonly in hands/feet
    • may have mild endosteal scalloping
    • should not 'grow' through cortex (unless a pathological fracture)

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no2921

questions.text: A patient had a history of twisting injury to the knee. He presented with pain and difficulty in walking. On doing an MRI, the structure marked in the image was damaged. What is the structure shown?
questions.solution:
• The structure in the above image represents the anterior cruciate ligament of the knee joint.
  • The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is a band of dense connective tissue which courses from the femur to the tibia.
  • The ACL is a key structure in the knee joint, as it resists anterior tibial translation and rotational loads.
  • Arises from the posteromedial corner of medial aspect of lateral femoral condyle in the intercondylar notch.
  • This femoral attachment of ACL is on posterior part of medial surface of lateral condyle well posterior to longitudinal axis of the femoral shaft.
  • The attachment is actually an interdigitation of collagen fibres & rigid bone thru transitional zone of
  • fibrocartilage and mineralized fibrocartilage. It runs inferiorly, medially and anteriorly. Anterior to the inter-condyloid eminence of the tibia, being blended with the anterior horn of the medial meniscus

Reference: Musculoskeletal MRI, second edition page 367

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows knee joint effusion. It is shown by fluid in the joint cavity and the surrounding recesses.
  • Joint Effusion can be caused by a number of reasons: Overusing the joint and causing repetitive injury from sports or household tasks. Tearing ligaments or cartilage Bacterial infection.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1417

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Osteoid osteomas are benign bone-forming tumors that typically occur in children (particularly adolescents).
  • They have a characteristic lucent nidus <1.5 or 2 cm and surrounding osteosclerotic reaction, which classically causes night pain that is relieved by the use of NSAIDs.
  • CT is excellent at characterizing the lesion and is the modality of choice. It typically shows a focally lucent nidus within surrounding sclerotic reactive bone. A central sclerotic dot may also be seen.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 969

questions.text: What view of the hip joint is being shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• The frog leg lateral view is a special radiograph of the pelvis to evaluate the hip.
  • Some departments will perform this routinely instead of the AP pelvis view to reduce exposure and maintain high diagnostic accuracy.
  • Bilateral examination allows for better visualization of the hip joints and femoral neck.
  • It is almost exclusively used in the paediatric population. It is an important view in the assessment of:
  • slipped capital femoral epiphysis
  • Perthes disease

Reference: Pant, H., Murphy, A. Pediatric hip (frog leg lateral view). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-24499

questions.text: A patient presented with 6 months of amenorrhea and underwent a USG examination of the foetus. One of the images during the scan is shown below. Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
• The placenta is a fetal organ of pregnancy, responsible for providing nutrition and oxygen to the fetus as well as excretory functions.
  • Ultrasound is the first-line modality in imaging the placenta due its wide availability and its use of non-ionizing radiation.
  • The placenta appears as a uniformly echogenic (intermediate echogenicity) structure along uterine wall, with a deep hypoechoic band separating it from normal uterine myometrium.
  • This retroplacental hypoechoic band is vital to rule out implantation disorders and its normal appearance should not be confused with retroplacental hematoma. There may also be numerous anechoic areas, representing venous lakes, within the placenta itself.

Reference: Jha, P., Jones, J. Placenta. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-23749

questions.text: Which of the following artery is used in management of fetal anemia?
questions.solution:
• Fetal Doppler US of the middle cerebral artery is used in two situations: (a) non-invasive assessment of fetal anemia and (b) calculation of cerebroplacental ratio as a measure of fetal brain sparing.
  • In response to hypoxia, the fetus diverts blood flow to the brain, increasing the middle cerebral artery diastolic flow, thereby decreasing the pulsatility index and altering the ratio of the umbilical artery flow to the middle cerebral artery flow.

Reference: A Radiologist';s Guide to the Performance and Interpretation of Obstetric Doppler US

Anne M. Kennedy and Paula J. Woodward

RadioGraphics 2019 39:3, 893-910

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with post-menopausal bleeding. On doing an USG examination, the endometrium was observed to be 10 mm. What is the normal limit of endometrium in postmenopausal women?
questions.solution:
• A double-layer thickness of less than 5 mm without focal thickening excludes significant disease and is consistent with atrophy.
  • Homogeneous, smooth endometrium measuring 5 mm or less are considered within the normal range with or without hormonal replacement therapy.

Reference: Imaging the Endometrium: Disease and Normal Variants

Kenneth M. Nalaboff, John S. Pellerito, and Eran Ben-Levi

RadioGraphics 2001 21:6, 1409-1424

questions.text: Which of the following is generally not seen during FAST examination?
questions.solution:
The following parts are visualised in FAST according to the protocol

  1. Hepatorenal pouch
  2. Splenorenal pouch
  3. Urinary bladder and pelvis
  4. Free fluid.

Reference: Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) in 2017: What Radiologists Can Learn, John R. Richards and John P. McGahan, Radiology 2017 283:1, 30-48.

questions.text: A patient had a history of trauma with a hammer and was suspected to have a foreign body within the orbit or the eyeball. Which of the following modality is contraindicated in such cases?
questions.solution:
Absolute contraindications for MRI is:

  1. Internal cardiac pacemaker
  2. Implantable cardiac defibrillator
  3. Cochlear implants
  4. Neurostimulators
  5. Bone growth stimulators
  6. Electrically programmed drug infusion pumps, vascular access ports
  7. Intraocular foreign body
  8. non-titanium aneurysm clips.

Reference: MRI made easy edition 2, page 90

questions.text: A patient presented with abnormal TFT. On doing an USG examination, a nodule was found in thyroid gland. It was given a TI-RADS score of 3. It measures 2.5 cm in size. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution: Reference: Jha, P., Weerakkody, Y. Thyroid imaging reporting and data system (TI-RADS). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-21448

questions.text: A patient presented with blunt abdominal trauma on the left side of abdomen. On doing a FAST examination, gross hemoperitoneum was observed. It was decided that the patient needed a CECT of the abdomen. On doing a CECT, AAST grade V injury was observed in the spleen. Which image best corresponds to AAST grade V injury of spleen?
questions.solution:
• Splenic trauma can occur after blunt or penetrating trauma or secondary to medical intervention (i.e. iatrogenic).
  • The spleen is the most frequently injured internal organ after blunt trauma.
  • Splenic parenchyma should be assessed in portal venous phase as the inhomogeneous splenic enhancement (zebra or psychedelic spleen) seen on arterial phase can mimic splenic laceration/contusion; arterial phase scanning can be useful in detecting vascular injuries such as pseudoaneurysm and AV fistula.
  • Lacerations appear as linear or branching hypodensities (geographic pattern)

Reference: Knipe, H., Botz, B. Splenic trauma. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-26342

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with abdominal distension. On doing a USG the following image was obtained along with gross ascites. From the image given below, what is the most likely cause of ascites?
questions.solution:
• Cirrhosis (plural: cirrhoses) is the common endpoint of a wide variety of chronic liver disease processes which cause hepatocellular necrosis.
  • Cirrhosis can be diagnosed with ultrasound, CT, and MRI, and these imaging modalities can also be used to evaluate for possible complications of cirrhosis, such as portal hypertension or hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Frequent findings in advanced cirrhosis include hypertrophy of the caudate lobe and lateral segments of the left lobe (segments 2 and 3) with concomitant atrophy of the posterior segments (6 and 7) of the right lobe.
  • Ultrasound is a major screening tool for cirrhosis and its complications. It is also useful to aid for biopsy. Appearances include:
  • surface nodularity:
  • overall coarse and heterogeneous echotexture
  • segmental hypertrophy/atrophy
  • signs of portal hypertension
  • Splenomegaly
  • Ascites
  • fatty change (variable)

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1862

questions.text: Water lily sign in seen in?
questions.solution:
Hydatid cysts result from infection by the Echinococcus tapeworm species and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body.

The USG features are The Gharbi ultrasound classification consists of five stages :

  • stage 1: homogeneously hypoechogenic cystic thin-walled lesion
  • stage 2: septated cystic lesion
  • stage 3: cystic lesion with daughter lesions
  • stage 4: pseudo-tumor lesion
  • stage 5: calcified or partially calcified lesion (inactive cyst)

The cysts usually have three components:

Peri-cyst: composed of inflammatory tissue of host origin
Exo-cyst
endo-cyst: scolices (the larval stage of the parasite) and the laminated membrane are produced here

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1893

questions.text: Identify the following condition of gall bladder.
questions.solution:
Adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder is a hyperplastic cholecystosis of the gallbladder wall. It is a relatively common and benign cause of diffuse or focal gallbladder wall thickening, most easily seen on ultrasound and MRI.

On USG it shows the following features:mural thickening (diffuse, focal, annular)

  • segmental/annular form is especially difficult to distinguish from gallbladder carcinoma.
  • comet-tail artifact: echogenic intramural foci from which emanate V-shaped comet tail reverberation artifacts are highly specific for adenomyomatosis, representing the unique acoustic signature of cholesterol crystals within the lumina of Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1991

questions.text: Which focal hepatic lesion is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is a regenerative mass lesion of the liver and the second most common benign liver lesion (most common is a hemangioma).
  • Focal nodular hyperplasia is most frequently found in young to middle-aged adults, with a strong female predilection.
  • FNH demonstrates bright homogeneous arterial contrast enhancement except for the central scar which remains hypoattenuating. Enlarged central arteries may be seen.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1881

questions.text: A 4-year-old patient presented with acute onset abdominal pain. What is the 1st line of investigation in such case?
questions.solution:
• The patient is presented with acute abdomen. In acute abdomen the investigation of choice is CECT abdomen but in paediatric patients the IOC is USG.
  • As CECT abdomen exposes the child to harmful radiation, USG is preferred.
  • Also, the child may not lie still in scanning machine and need sedation which increases other risks.
  • Thus, in paediatric patients USG is the investigation of choice in acute abdomen.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2079

questions.text: 'Double bubble' sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
• In the image given above there is presence of 2 air-fluid levels within the abdomen.
  • This is suggestive of duodenal atresia as the one air fluid level is of fundic gas shadow and the other is of duodenum.
  • As the continents cannot pass further int eh abdomen beyond the duodenum it accumulates and gives rise to another air-fluid level.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1092

questions.text: A patient presented with loss of appetite and weight loss. He underwent a CECT abdomen which is shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Adenocarcinoma represents approximately 95 percent of all gastric malignancies and usually occurs in the fifth or sixth decade of life.
  • Prognosis depends upon the tumor stage at the time of diagnosis.
  • Five-year survival rates decrease from 90 percent in early-stage disease to less than 20 percent in advanced malignancy.
  • CT is the imaging modality of choice for locoregional gastric cancer staging, and PET CT is helpful for evaluating for distant spread.
  • The primary tumor may appear as a focal mass, an ulcerated mass, or as a diffusely infiltrative process involving the gastric wall.
  • Diffusely infiltrative tumors may be desmoplastic, stiffening the gastric wall that results in the linitis plastica pattern.
  • Irregularity of the outer gastric contour, extension into the peri-gastric fat, and adjacent organ invasion can indicate the extent of local disease.
  • CT is also used for the assessment of lymph node involvement, hematogenous spread to the liver, and direct seeding of the peritoneum with tumor involvement of the pelvis and ovaries.

Reference: Gastrointestinal Imaging Cases, Angela D. Levy, Koenraad J. Mortele, and Benjamin M. Yeh; page 56

questions.text: A patient is a known case of sickle cell anaemia. On examination for breathlessness, doing a CT scan of thorax the following image was obtained. What is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• Sickle cell anaemia is the most common genetic disorder affecting African Americans with a prevalence of 1 in 375, and a heterozygous gene carrier rate of 1 in 12.
  • Sickle cell anaemia is a haemolytic anaemia characterized by abnormally shaped ('sickled') red blood cells, which are destroyed at increased rates, leading to anaemia.
  • Of greater clinical importance, the sickled red blood cells cause vascular occlusion, which leads to tissue ischemia and infarction.
  • Many organ systems throughout the body are affected. leading to characteristic findings on imaging.
  • The spleen is particularly susceptible to ischemia/infarction due to its slow microcirculation, and over time this results in auto-splenectomy.
  • Current data show that at the age of 2 years 58 percent of sickle cell anaemia patients are functionally asplenic, with an increase to 94 percent of patients by 5 years of age.
  • On radiographs or CT, the spleen in patients with sickle cell anaemia can appear small in size, dense, and calcified.
  • MRI typically shows loss of signal in the splenic parenchyma on both T1 and T2 imaging due to fibrosis and ferro-calcinosis.

Reference: Gastrointestinal Imaging Cases, Angela D. Levy, Koenraad J. Mortele, and Benjamin M. Yeh; page 328

questions.text: Which type of cyst is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Bosniak classification is a system to classify the cystic renal masses into benign and malignant and is based on CT appearance of the lesion.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no110

questions.text: Identify the abnormality shown in the intravenous pyelography image shown below.
questions.solution:
A retrocaval ureter (aka circum-caval ureter) is a congenital anomaly where the ureter passes behind the IVC leading to obstructive uropathy due to compression by the IVC.

Passing of ureter behind the IVC leads to J shaped IVP as shown in the image above due to compression by IVC of the ureter and resultant proximal hydronephrosis.

Reason for ureter lying posterior to IVC is actually due to abnormal embryological development of IVC.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 58

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Xantho-granulomatous pyelonephritis is a rare chronic granulomatous inflammation of the kidneys.
  • It is usually seen in patients with stones or obstruction.
  • On CT scan there are hypoattenuating masses which represent the dilated calyces filled with pus and necrotic debris and are separated by renal column of Bertine.
  • This leads to appearance of 'bear paw'.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 85

questions.text: For PIRADS scoring, which of the following sequences are not used?
questions.solution:
• PIRADS scoring is used in prostate for finding the probability of having a malignancy in a suspicious lesion. It is based on MRI technique.
  • On the basis of appearance of lesion on the various sequences of MRI the grading of the lesion is done. This is based on 3 sequences- T2WI, DYNAMIC CONTRAST, DWI.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 378

questions.text: Which of the following radiopharmaceutical is used in bone scan?
questions.solution:
• Bone scan has been available and used for decades to image the skeletal system. It is very sensitive for pathology; but lacks specificity.
  • It can image the entire skeletal system at a relatively low cost and therefore, remains popular for skeletal imaging.
  • The radiotracer most commonly used for bone scan is Tc-99m methylene diphosphonate (MDP), where technetium-99-m is the radioactive component and MDP the biological component.

Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology page 721

questions.text: A patient presented with RT-PCR positive for COVID-19 pneumonia. Which of the following is most commonly seen on HRCT in COVID 19 pneumonia?
questions.solution:
• Several chest CT findings have been reported in more than 70% of RT-PCR test-proven COVID-19 cases, including ground-glass opacities, vascular enlargement, bilateral abnormalities, lower lobe involvement, and posterior predilection.
  • In COVID-19 endemic regions, the observation of these chest CT findings should raise the suspicion of possible COVID-19 diagnosis

Reference: Chest CT in COVID-19: What the Radiologist Needs to Know Thomas C. Kwee and Robert M. Kwee RadioGraphics 2020 40:7, 1848-1865
